title: What are the best 5 cowboy or western movies of all time? - Quora

response.answer_text: 5. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966) - A rarity in that it is the third film in a trilogy, and the best. It follows A Fistful of Dollars and For a Few Dollars More. All three films are extremely low budget spaghetti westerns that find their strengths in those constraints. The film has one of the most recognizable music scores in film, by Ennio Moricone. Three criminals, played by Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef, and Eli Wallach, set out, during the Civil War, to find a cache of gold, hidden in a cemetery. Clint Eastwood's success in television had prevented his success in movies. This trilogy of films changed that.  4. Red River (1948) - Another Hawks/Wayne collaboration. In the Dark Knight, there's a line that goes: "You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain." Red River is an examination of that process. It is also a look at one of the legendary cattle drives from Texas to Kansas. Wayne plays Thomas Dunson, depicted over a 14 year period, as we watch him go from a young, ambitious white hat starting his ranch to a jaded, tired black hat cattle baron. It's also a story of the decline of the father and ascendancy of the son, with a young Montgomery Clift as Dunson's adopted son, Matt.  3. Stagecoach (1939) - This is the film that made John Wayne a star. He had had one chance at the A-list in a movie that failed and had spent a decade doing B-movies. But in John Ford's Stagecoach, he showed he had the stuff to be a star. Stagecoach is the archetype of the movie in which a group of very dissimilar people must come together to survive a great challenge. Wayne plays "The Ringo Kid" a fugitive intent on avenging the murder of his father and brother. Also on the stagecoach are a gunslinging gambler (played with mustache-twirling glee by John Carradine), a corrupt banker, a prostitute, an alcoholic doctor, a pregnant woman, a meek salesman, and a marshal. Their journey takes them through hazardous Apache territory which provides a stunning action scene as the stagecoach is chased across the desert by a swarm of Apache warriors. The stunt work is impressive, including a stunt in which a character is dragged under a team of horses and down the length of the stagecoach. It is this stunt to which the famed scene in Raiders of the Lost Ark pays homage.  2. Unforgiven (1992) - Unforgiven is Clint Eastwood's elegy to the western and his bookend to his career in westerns. He was 62 when he directed and starred in Unforgiven. He plays a former gunslinger named William Munny. He has long been settled down and away from that life. He married and had children and he has become a hog farmer. He is widowed and just trying to live out his days in peace, when he is lured back into a violent world. Unforgiven is its own story - well crafted and independent. But it shows influences and pays homage to almost every film on this list - most particularly Shane. The film respectfully illustrates the difference between truth and legend, as Munny tries to live down the mythology that grew about his younger self - the mythology that many earlier westerns were built around. Unforgiven manages to both dispel and live up to that mythology.  1. The Searchers (1956) - New York Magazine referred to The Searchers as the most influential film in the history of film. The Searchers was the ninth collaboration of director John Ford and actor John Wayne. It is based on the novel by Alan Le May, which, in turn, was based on the real historical Parker massacre and capture of Cynthia Parker by Comanche Indians. Wayne is compelling as Ethan Edwards, the uncle of a missing girl. He undertakes a years long search for his niece. His character hates the Comanche. He is unrepentantly racist towards them - hating them so much that he sees his mission as to find his niece and mercifully kill her because she will have been corrupted by the Indians.  If you’d like to see five more great all-time westerns, see my Quora movie blog post: Robert Frost's post in The Greatest Films or, if you prefer newer films, see Robert Frost's post in The Greatest Films

1.The Searchers: (1956) Directed by: Robert Ford Starring: John Wayne, Natalie Wood and Jeffrey Hunter  In this revered western, Ethan Edwards (John Wayne) returns home to Texas to find members of his family have been killed and abducted by comanches.. Vowing revenge, he sets of into the west to find and kill not only the comanches who murdered his family, but must stuggle with himself deciding whether or not he must kill his neice (Natalie Wood) as well, as she is now lost to the ways of her captors…. ☆ This movie explores a never before seen dark side of “The Duke” for the first time in his movie career… 2. The Good, The Bad, and The ugly: (1966) Directed by: Sergio Leone Starring: Clint Eastwood, Eli Wallach, and Lee Van Cleef  In this action paked western centered in the old Southwest of Mexico, a mysterious stranger named Joe (Clint Eastwood) forms an uneasy alliance with a Spanish drifter and thief (Eli Wallach) to find and steal 20,000 dollars hidden in a secret grave by the U.S Army, leading to a final showdown with a quick drawing gunslinger (Lee Van Cleef ) for the gold.. ☆ This movie cemented Clint Eastwood’s stardom as one of the greatest spaghetti western actors of the 20th century… 3. My Name is Nobody: (1973) Directed by: Tony Noveleri Starring: Henry Fonda, Terrence Hill, and Jean Martin  A well known extremely fast and skilled retired gunslinger (Henry Fonda) travels to New Orleans in order to board a boat bound for Europe in order to live the remainder of his days out in peace, but he is constantly shadowed by a equally skillful young gunfighter (Terrence Hill) who wants to kill him in a gunfight citing he should die a honorable and glorified death and showcase the young gunfighters skill as a gunslinger… But his plans (Henry Fonda) are put on hold as he crosses path with a band of 50 outlaws led by an old aquaintence (Jean Martin) intent on robbing a train, leading to one final act of skill and glory by the retired gunfighter to end the death and wanton destruction commited at the hands of the band of outlaws as they converge upon the train.. ☆ Henry Fonda gives one of the greatest performances of his life, and proves that he is and was one of the greatest actors of his time… 4. Once Upon A Time In The West: Directed by: Sergio Leone Starring: Charles Bronson, Henry Fonda, and Jason Robards  Sergio Leone's masterpiece of murder and revenge based in the old west, details the story of the mysterious and lethel gunfighter “Harmonica” in his quest for vengeance for the death of his brother against a band of renegade killers led by “Fred” (Henry Fonda) hired to kill a land owner for his land halting the progress of a railroad… ☆ This is Charles Bronson at his very best, and Henry Fonda and Jason Robards give stellar performances in one of the greatest western’s ever made…. 5. Sabata: (1969) Directed by: Giafranco Parolini Starring: Lee Van Cleef, Ignazio Spalla, and William Berger  Sabata (Lee Van Cleef) is a man of few words, who comes to a small town in Texas to foil a bank robbery, only to discover it is a ploy set up by local land barons to gain the town for a railroad company, he crosses path with a conflicted hired gun sent to kill him who goes by the name of Banjo (William Berger) so named for the rifle he hides in the instrument leading to one of the most action packed showdown’s in old western movie history… ☆ This is the first of three Italian spaghetti western's brought to the movie screen by Giafranco Parolini in the Sabata trilogy ●Honorable Mention The Magnificent Seven: (Original/1960) Directed by: John Sturges Starring: Yul Brenner, Steve McQueen, Charles Bronson, Robert Vaughn, James Colburn, Eli Wallach, and Horst Bolchholz  Terrorized by a brutal outlaw named Calvera and his henchmen, a small town hires seven gunfighters to challenge Calvera and free them from torment, teaching the townfolk to fight themselves, it sets the stage for the seven gunfighters and townsfolk for one of the most explosive and action packed showdown in old west movie history… ☆ This American spaghetti western packs an all-star cast of some of the greatest western actors of their generation, a must have for any western movie lovers collection….
